Comment: Exactly why I love coworking spaces. Working at home, I get distracted by home stuff - oh hey, let me do the laundry, my cat is bugging me, oh hey got a new magazine better read that! It's hard for me to easily switch from "relaxing at home" to "work mode", and then back again (trying to sleep and realizing there's still an email I should've sent or yadda yadda). Having an office space to go to compels me to go work, and it's really no different in distraction from other offices I've been in, since the "open plan" office is the norm now so there's always times to get distracted. But having the opportunity to network with people I ordinarily wouldn't be able to network with with my small 4-person team, being able to get away from my house and get into "work mode" like any other professional, that's why I love cowork spaces. The free coffee and beer and yoga discounts is a nice perk tho.

If the United States has 197 archdioceses and dioceses, I wonder how many ordinaries are using this administrator title excessively. 
----
When the Archdiocese of New York merged and "closed" parishes in August, 2015, quite a few mere administrators were appointed. Upon hearing just a few stories about administrators who were bad fits, I wondered whether the Cardinal Archbishop was not only short priests but also (hate to say it) short of pastors who could get along with the active groups of parishioners. To put it another way, to what extent is this tactic a way of bullying priests into submission, or a realization that pastoral talent is in short supply?

Comment: I support the concept of the jail and have voted for every levy, so far.  Not this one.  At some point in my opinion, law enforcement, including a city jail, has to be funded at least in part by regular revenue.  I didn't hear of any serious discussion by the City Council or city manager about looking for ways to supplement the current levy rate of $1.28 with funding from the city's general tax revenue.  With the levy funding, the discussion is always about the taxpayers either keeping the level of jail services or losing them if the levy is not renewed/increased.  Why not some discussion about maybe losing some planning department personal versus jail personnel?  "Short term" levies becoming part of the basic city services is one reason why property taxes are becoming a major burden on many fixed income citizens.

Comment: "What causes gentrification is rich people moving here. "

Nope. It's the uncontrolled housing market that causes gentrification. As neighborhoods become more desirable, the market allows rich people to compete amongst each other and drive prices up. They are also able to privately capture the value that is added with things like infrastructure improvements, even though those things are publicly funded. But it's possible to control this with things like Community Land Trusts. Rich people are only able to drive up prices because our uncontrolled, private market, that treats housing as just another commodity rather than a human right, allows it. 

Sustainable living for the rich, while everybody else gets pushed to the suburbs, is not Climate Justice. It's actually a grave injustice to all the people who want to live in a sustainable Portland but are basically being told they don't deserve to because they don't make enough money. Fix that and people might get on board with development.

Comment: !%ers refer to income, not assets. They are 1% but only because they work so much. 

The vast majority of that asset base is the house, which is not particularly meaningful since it's completely unrealized and very speculative.  Even a small real estate correction will knock a hundred grand off each's net worth. Go back to year-ago valuations, and their net worth is halved. 

I would also argue that the commuted value of a DB pension plan is also meaningless since it's not liquid either, and should be considered in terms of retirement-era cash flow rather than lump sum value, akin to CPP or OAS, neither of which are assets in their own rights. 

 When you look at their actual liquid assets, he's worth 19k and she's worth 36, or 19k once the car is paid off. Neither number is particularly impressive given their savings capacity and plans.

Comment: Excellent well-written article.  Full disclosure:  I have been a volunteer on the PWSRCAC Scientific Advisory Committee since 2003.  I would note that some of the analogies given here by commenters are inappropriate. A better one is to ask whether SCUBA divers should practice dealing with sudden unexpected crises, such as running out of air.  I still remember during my training having the instructor come up behind me and turn off my air. Pilots learn to do emergency landings on unexpected runways. One pilot was able to land an out-of-fuel Boeing 767 on an abandoned runway because he had experience as a glider pilot. No we don't set people's homes on fire for training purposes, but training often includes setting fire to abandoned barns and other buildings so firefighters-in-training can practice dealing with them.

Comment: The Church's sacramental theology largely derives from the Council of Trent's response to the Protestant Reformation and, beyond that, to the adoption of Aristotelian categories by medieval philosophers and theologians. In this way, the Church has argued that the species of bread and wine become the "substance" of the body, blood, soul and divinity of Jesus Christ, even as the "accidents" of bread and wine remain. Thus, according to Trent and prior councils, anyone who approaches the sacrament in the state of sin does so unworthily (borrowing a Pauline phrase) and commits a sin. 
Vatican II largely reaffirmed the sacramental theology of Trent while simultaneously pointing to a broader, less Aristotelian understanding of sacraments. Theologians have followed that direction in laying our a much more biblical and dynamic understanding of how God becomes present to us through the sacraments. But the official Church has not yet made the transition and people are feeling the consequences.

Comment: Not nearly as dumb as claiming the Deity's Name isn't "Allah", or foisting homosexual King James as some kind of "religious authority".  (Sigh) again--here's how it works:

Allah & Allahumma (Arabic) = Alah & Alaha (old Aramaic) = Elah & Elohim (Hebrew).

Those Semitic Names have likewise been translated as Olah (Zulu), Khuda (Farsi), Bogu (Russian), Dieu (French), Atu'a (Samoan), El Dio (Spanish), Hotheos (Greek), Astvats (Armenian), Bog (Hungarian), Xwede (Khurdish), Gott (German) and...GOD (English).

Arabic CHRISTIANS have ALWAYS invoked the Deity by the Name ALLAH.  So did the Messiah (alayhis-Salaam) when he (allegedly) cried out "Eli, Eli lama sabachthani!" from the cross.  The Greeks transliterated "Allah" as "Eli".

Glad I could help.  Anything else you wanna know about the Scriptures and/or their languages, just ask.  Or,  you can adopt the standard "evangelical logic" so succinctly described by Bill Watterson: "Why expend effort learning when ignorance is instantaneous?"

Comment: Tsunami is more than a Bookstore.  For 22 years we have served as a Community and Cultural Center at 2585 Willamette in Eugene, Or.  Over 4000 free or affordable events have been hosted.  Our lease is up come June 30, 2017.  But 2585 Willamette is our second living room, and we want to stay.  With your help Tsunami intends to raise $400,000. by March 30, 2017, which will secure the next 5 year lease with options.  Tsunami is sstill a young, growing institution with a long-term committment, substantial sales and the potential to greatly increase options for the community, arts, and our sustainability.  Our website-- tsunamibooks.org --has a "Pledge" Page.  There is also a "Words" Page,  where you will find a number of pieces entitled "The Future Of Tsunami Books," which describes our thoughts and plans.  Better, drop by the Bookstore and ask about what's up.  On the first day of our pledge campaign, over 500 people came through, and $35,000 in pledges was raised.  Scott Landfield

If we were intelligently planning for the future we would be planning to manage a steady contraction of population, not expansion.

Comment: I think the city uses a software program to do it's real property assessments. I believe it's a canned program used by other municipalities. The assessor still go out because they have to Value things such as improvements as well as validate new construction. during acquisitions fair market value is used.  Fair market value is defined by the uniform appraisal standards. Appraisals are really best estimates of market value. The appraiser has a lot of leeway in terms of valuations adjustments to valuations and capitalization rates. In the eminent domain cases I've been involved with I have never seen a landowner recoup enough in terms of market value to cover his legal expenses. Most people Take the Money and Run because they can reinvest the money in a similar asset without paying capital gains taxes.  So if a landowner's asset has appreciated 200% over 20 years he can capture that increase without cap gain taxes

Comment: I find it interesting that the analysis states that "there have been minimal studies associated specifically with military jet noise." while the draft EIS appears to leverage the lack of research by stating "there are no studies that definitively show a causal and significant relationship between aircraft noise and health." 

That's something to note. If there have been minimal studies performed, I would say the draft EIS comment about "no studies" is somewhat misleading. If there is a lack of, or only very minimal, research on the subject, a scientist would be hard pressed to prove or disprove any hypothesis related to the question at hand. 

I know that studies are expensive and can take time to complete; however, with the apparent lack of research available it might be an opportunity to examine the issue using the scientific method to provide us with more information?

Comment: What I really don't understand about the rational behind making gun control one of the major platforms for half of the country is that it is not the best use of the limited resource that is our national attention span.  

I don't disagree that the country needs to find a way to curb violent homicides, assaults and accidental death, but taking away guns isn't where we can do the most good - not even slightly.

Guns were involved in 1.3% of all deaths in 2013 - that included 11,208 by homicide, 21,175 by suicide and 505 in cases like this, accidental shootings.  

100% of the deaths by suicide could potentially have been prevented by better mental health care and probably 75-80% of the homicides could have been prevented if the perpetrators had better economic opportunities.

Meanwhile heart disease took 611,105 people, cancer 584,881, respiratory diseases 149,205, mechanical accidents and drowning  130,052, and strokes killed 128,978. Being unhealthy, stupid and smoking are the issues.

Comment: Whoever authorized the headline "American Lung Association gives Lane County air quality an 'F'" deliberately deceived RG readers. As someone who grew up in Los Angeles during the 1960s, this headline caught my eye. However, the story revealed the truth, but only between the lines: the F was limited to short-term air quality problems, primarily the forest fire days during the summer.  Everyone around here already knows the air was awful during that period, so here's the so-called news: the American Lung Assoc determined that Lane County's air deserved an F while the fires burned. Well, duh: that's hardly news. Meanwhile, the deceptive and shameful headline implies our air quality deserves an F throughout the year, when, in fact, that's not true. I grew up where ozone levels deserved an F just about every day, except for periods immediately after it rained. Los Angeles in 1965 deserved the headline, not Eugene in 2015. Should the RG seek respect or the reputation of a tabloid?

Comment: Kaniela Ing, Hawaii legislature committee chairman, unethically disappeared written testimony by Ken Conklin on two different bills on the same day this year.

Kaniela Ing's bill would enact into law a racial restriction on who can run for OHA trustee.  In year 2000 the U.S. Supreme Court ruled (Rice v. Later 2 federal courts ruled (Arakaki vs. State of Hawaii) that it is unconstitutional to have a racial restriction on who can RUN as a candidate for OHA. Comment: I strongly support basic shelter, nutrition, safety and medical care for all individuals who will not harm others or jeopardize others' right to the same. Our civilization is wealthy enough to manage that, even for "lazy" individuals; and it would be simpler to let a few "sponges" benefit rather than sustaining a massive bureaucracy to determine who "deserves" these basics and who does not.

I also strongly support some forms of incentive to have well-thought-out, cost-effective architecture - the exact opposite of what Piercy and Ruiz did with Capstone and are doing with the City Hall.

But "housing need" is not an ethical justification for degrading the livability of people's neighborhoods, which is what the "true believers" in Eugene claim is justified. Degrading established neighborhoods is also counter-productive and inequitable. Economically mobile households will simply move to an acceptable alternative, and less well-off will be stuck with less desirable neighborhoods.
 
Paul

Comment: They advise park visitors to wear little bells on their clothes so they make noise when hiking. The bell noise allows bears to hear them coming from a distance and not be startled by a hiker accidentally sneaking up on them. This might cause a bear to charge.
Visitors should also carry a pepper spray can just in case a bear is encountered. Spraying the pepper into the air will irritate the bear's sensitive nose and it will run away.
It is also a good idea to keep an eye out for fresh bear scat so you have an idea if bears are in the area. People should be able to recognize the difference between black bear and grizzly bear scat.
Black bear droppings are smaller and often contain berries, leaves, and possibly bits of fur. Grizzly bear droppings tend to contain small bells and smell of pepper.

Comment: The reason for the dominance of Ontario and Quebec is because we have a larger population - there are exceptions PEI has 4 seats and a population smaller than the town I live in an only has 1 seat.

The seats in the HC are mostly apportioned based on Population - so as an area grows riding's are realigned or seats are added.  The point of the electoral college in the US is to elect the President, something similar here would not work as we do not directly elect the Prime Minster.  

The leader of party winning the most seats gets to be PM. For the Electoral college to be similar to Canada we would either have to vote a second time for PM or the majority of the Congress and Senate in the US would have to chose the President.

BTW the Senate was supposed to account for regional differences with smaller Population provinces being guaranteed a minimum number of senators

Race and the advocacy of private gun ownership are inextricably-linked in the USA.  The "well-regulated militias" were not about fending off the British. Comment: Just a few days ago, I read a story in an advice column where the purchaser came back to the buyer and said the bank had downgraded the value of the recently purchased (but not yet closed) house by $100,000 and so they weren't willing to give him the same size of mortgage. So he couldn't pay for the house. (What ever happened to pre-approved mortgages, eh?)

The seller of course could have just kept the deposit. But the advice was interesting. 

If the seller just kept the deposit, he'd still have to sell the house. So would he get the same money now as opposed to a few months ago? 

The advice was that the seller should consider offering to give the buyer a second mortgage to make up the difference. The sale could then go through without the vendor having to reduce his price.

Comment: I believe admonishment of the OP is unwarranted in this case. It is imperative that dialogue take place in civil aviation regarding accidents, as soon as possible. It is true that final conclusions should be left to the experts however many times valuable lessons can be gleaned from early assessments resulting in operating procedures being altered which sometimes saves lives. NTSB accident investigations are indeed necessary, unfortunately, these are a long time in coming, by the time they are released the media and other aviators have lost interest.

There is a degree of merit in the OPs observations in this case. Having logged hundreds of hours as pilot in command doing aerial surveys with fixed wing aircraft, primarily low level salmon spawning stream counts, I learned that it is very important to keep the aircraft as light as possible, if unable to do that alter the survey procedure---- i.e. higher altitudes and shallower turns.

The Cessna 170-B is somewhat of a "dog", loaded.

Comment: Proposed Amendment to the Oregon Constitution:

No holder of any public office, regularly and ordinarily filled by election, of the State of Oregon or any of its political subdivisions, shall be a member of the Oregon Public Employee Retirement System because of  his or her work or service in that elective office.  Elected county sheriffs  shall be exempt from this provision. No mandatory, contractual or voluntary contributions from such elected officials shall be accepted into the System during the period of elected service after the effective date of this Act.  No future System benefits shall be computed or paid based upon elected service rendered after the effective date of this Act.  This Act shall be effective immediately upon passage by the vote of the people.

Ballot title:

Amends Oregon Constitution to eliminate elected officials from the Public Employment Retirement System, exempts Sheriffs.


Friendly amendments will be accepted through the first day to file.

Comment: Rather than buying back and reselling affordable units I'd rather have the agency focus on financing the units - a public-private partnership.

Comment: Clearly I never denied a certain unpredictability since I in multiple places mentioned our cooperation.   

I reject the word random however for a very substantial reason.

There's more than chance involved.  There's virtue, which is a natural faculty God invented and put in us:  an ability to grow toward the good.  Virtue happens when good acts are repeated, tending to make our response to God's will less random, and more inclined to the good.

People who understand what virtue is (dispositions/habits to do good) and who assiduously work to increase their virtue will on average respond to moral choices toward choosing (and toward doing) the good.

That's not random.

Comment: I think the value of this survey has lost a lot of it's value over time.  At one time the differences were far more notable and more likely to have an impact on the general level of satisfaction. But the majority of the variances within the rather absurd list of 40 Attributes comes down to niche issues or minor irritants.  In other word nothing that is going to prompt you to cross the street.

For those prospective DIY investors trying to manage a list of 40 attributes across 12 brokers isn't particularly helpful.  Distill the issues down into a manageable list:
1.) Cost
2.) Security 
3.) Platform structure including mobile options
4.) Range of investment options
5.) Access to foreign denominated accounts both cash and registered
6.) Access to Research and Analytical tools
7.) Customer Service

Comment: That is not true. Dilbit is now worse than light oil spills depending on the sea conditions and the clean-up response.

http://oils.gpa.unep.org/facts/fate.htm

Also, a recent Government of Canada study has shown the dilbit floats on freshwater.

http://www.financialpost.com/m/wp/executive/blog.html?b=business.financialpost.com/news/energy/study-showing-that-spilled-oilsands-crude-floats-on-fresh-water-could-help-unlock-stalled-pipelines

Also, dilbit is currently being shipped in batches on the existing Transmountain pipeline. Future mining production will see paraffinic froth treatment dilbit with an API of 18 or so. Read up on it. It is a cleaner refinery ready product than napthenic bilbit (cut with condensate).

And finally, even if 'refining' it in Alberta were economic, Alberta's GHG emissions would really escalate and effectively double the overall GHG count because it would be upgraded and then refined at destination.

Comment: Canaries in the coal mine? The cold water upwellings that bring the deep water nutrients closer to the surface where the krill feed on them which in turn support these birds and our fisheries could be breaking down from the warmer waters in the North Pacific. Think of it as a conveyor belt moving cold nutrient rich water to the surface where it can be utilized by the small crustaceans and copepods that herring and these birds feed on. What people don't realize is this system is the foundation of the entire food chain in this ecosystem. It breaks down and everything that depends on it, including us suffer. Comment: Models, especially computer models only work when you can include all possible variables.

With climate thats an impossibility, we don't know the temperatures or precipitation that will occur in the coming weeks, months or years. We don't know cloud cover, or what volcanic eruptions, forest fires or earthquakes will occur and all of these things plus many more affect future climate.

Computer models do one thing, they provide a result based upon the variables (data) provided in the programming. Alter the data and you get a different result. Climate model results are never factual, since the variables used are best guesses of future events.

- Sort out the native status
- Cut Canada tie to British Crown, replace all powers come from the new Constitution
- Revamp Provincial powers, transfer some to federal to make the country more integrated. 
- Consolidate the Maritime provinces
- Remove religion special status

Couillard have not spelled out what he wants. But I figure he would be happy with getting rid of the British Crown in exchange for no special status for any provinces.

Comment: "WRONG! Prior to the ACA [people at various risk] didn't [get policies all the time without Insurance companies knowing about it]."

**How silly: you've obviously never heard of  'adverse selection' - (http://www.investopedia.com/terms/a/adverseselection.asp) is a factual, known phenomenon that has taken place as long as insurance markets have been in existence.  Have you never taken Econ 101? You never had to read Akerlof's 'Market for Lemons?'   Insurance companies build this known fact into their pricing models: they know that people with higher risks can evade and not report their true risks when seeking coverage-- smokers and those with family histories of a certain malady do this every single day.  That you simply deny this is absolutely silly.

Comment: If your account is factual, I suspect a family of ermine moved into your neighborhood at more or less the same time.  I have witnessed mass-migration of rats away from a site shortly after ermine moved in.  This was in Kodiak, and I've heard of the same thing from others whose opinion I trust.

Mustelids (weasels, etc.) are much better mousers/ratters than cats.  One species was domesticated for this purpose long before cats were.  I've seen mink eliminate rodents from a Sitka property to where their rodent traps stayed empty for years.

It's also only fair to say I believe NO anecdotes from cat-nutters, because "anecdote" is to them a euphemism for lying through their teeth.  So forgive me if your "screen name" causes me to regard your claim with skepticism.

Ermine scent drives away commensal rodents.  Cat scent attracts them if they're infected with toxoplasmosis.  This facilitates the pathogens' return to feline digestive tracts, which is the only place they can reproduce.

Comment: My insurance, which has been the same company for 19 years  now *and* passed muster with ACA so remained totally unchanged as far as coverage, increased very little, and twice, decreased. Then along came ACA...

Non-payers costs are added to the Payers medical bills by the providers, not the insurance.

You can say I am full of it but my experience is what I am telling you. I do have each years rates saved. And I have several friends who will tell you the exact same thing.

There is no such thing as free-somebody pays. The use of emergency room as the 'family doctor' has increased, not decreased, under ACA. That costs the payers like me. 

Bottom line, health care is not a "right' in this country. I am all for emergency get them stable (only) care. I am all for one free well check visit a year. After that-they need to pay just like they pay for everything else. Or forgo treatment. That is their choice.

Is CAPE useful? Sure as general background information if you want to know if the market is currently cheap or expensive.   Should anyone use it to make investment decisions today?  Doubtful.

Comment: Russell, you are attempting to justify a situation you don't completely understand. I think by "west" of the river you mean north of the South Fork of Campbell Creek. Singletrack Advocates have already drawn up plans for trails in that area as well. They were shelved about 10 years ago in the latest version of the park trails plan because of concerns about bears. I won't be surprised if the plans resurface in the future with the growing demand for more advanced singletrack trails. 

And you're assuming the bears will just move over a bit and confine their travel to a narrow strip on the north side of the creek. Good luck with that.

We've already experienced what might happen when you cram a bunch of singletrack trails into an area that already has a mountain bike trail (e.g., Spencer's Loop). The example is Kincaid Park, where the number of moose attacks on bikers skyrocketed after the singletrack trails were added.

Comment: monkey,

While far from being a supporter of any of Canada's various Federal or Provincial conservative Parties, I do think that democracy works best for us when viable conservative and social democratic Parties can challenge the generally dominant centrist (usually Liberal) Parties. 

This is not the case when more ideological and doctrinally fundamentalist elements gain the upper hand of Parties on the Left or Right.  I'm not saying that social conservatives and free-market purists shouldn't have a home in a conservative Party (or that socialist,  syndicalist and environmental purist elements shouldn't have a home within a big tent NDP); rather my point is that other more moderate and less intense elements need to predominate if such Right or Left Parties are to avoid disappearing down some blind alley to oblivion on the political landscape.

In short, I agree with you that the likes of Chong and Khan are the way forward rather than Leitch or Kenney.

Comment: It is extremely unlikely that the auditor's office will find $700K in recurring savings every year to cover its budget. The person who stands to benefit the most from this measure is whoever gets elected into this position, which is more likely to be a politician than a professional auditor.

Comment: Katzke's desire to protect her son is admirable, but the part of it that consists of attempting to prevent his exposure to internet content is futile.  Children much younger than her son are already aware that the online world is the real world, in the sense of it's the place the information is and the place things happen fast.  They are drawn to that world the same way our generation was drawn to television, irresistibly, even when our parents discouraged it.  My parents refused to buy one, because they didn't like its influence.  I just watched it at my friends' houses.  It's no easier to deny access to the internet than it was to deny access to television.  I suggest Katzke assume that her son will, if he wishes to, see whatever he wants to see on the internet.  He will probably participate in discussions.  Don't issue useless prohibitions or spy on him.  Talk with him and guide his judgment.  If he basically trusts his parents, he's unlikely to do anything seriously foolish.

Comment: Canada used to spend 2% of its GDP on military during the Cold War. As stated in this article it is down to less than 1% today. Largely because governments since 1990 have taken a "peace dividend" and reduced the budget. Now that the world is becoming a more dangerous place it is time to reevaluate whether we are adequately protected from new threats - cyber warfare, asymmetrical threats (terrorism) and protection of our undersea territory (e.g. northwest passage).

Canada had agreed to double spending to 2% of GDP to support NATO but I would argue that was done without a complete needs assessment. We don't know if 2% is more or less than what is needed.

Comment: Question:  Why do we want to increase the total number of voters?  Even asking this question in America in public is seen as blasphemy, but if you go into the political science or economics department of any university, it's a valid question.

Voter ignorance is not only the strongest finding in political science, it may even be the strongest finding in all of social science.  It is so well supported by the evidence that it has never seriously been contested since it was first studied back in the 50's.  To my knowledge, there are no political scientists who believe that voters are not ignorant. Not even one.  

Now, there are competing theories for WHY voters are so ignorant, but nobody disputes the fact that they are, in fact, ignorant of politics.

It seems like we'd be better off trying to educate and inform those who are already voting before we increase the total number of ignorant voters.  I don't see what increasing the total number of ignorant voters would accomplish.

Comment: Women certainly had a profound effect on the practice of medicine. The first generation of women worked exactly like men to gain acceptance into a profession with long hours and high responsibility. The second generation appeared in greater numbers on medical committees suggesting ideas of their own such as job-sharing,  parental leave, and changes to our work environments that made the specialties more "female friendly". The third generation implemented these changes, forming a better balance between family and professional obligations.
The interesting thing was that male physicians then started making similar changes in their practices. The women had taught us how to practice without destroying our family lives. 
In the 1970s I knew a female colleague who worked in the office while having her contractions. When they became severe she called her obstetrician, and had her baby 2 hours later. Two days after delivery she was back in the office. These days - fortunately - are long gone.

Comment: I agree. Lets get our definitions right.

DACA was "Nonimmigrant" but now is/will be "Illegal Alien" as soon as their temporary status is not renewed. (Refer to #4 - 'Illegal alien:  an alien who entered the United States legally but who has fallen "out of status" and is deportable.')


Correct terminology, continuing on:

#1-Immigrant-An alien who has been granted the right by the USCIS to reside permanently in the United States
#2-Nonimmigrant-An alien who has been granted the right by the USCIS to reside temporarily in the United States. 
#3-Alien-An individual who is not a U.S. citizen or U.S. national.
#4-Illegal Alien- Also known as an "Undocumented Alien," is an alien who has entered the United States illegally and is deportable if apprehended, or an alien who entered the United States legally but who has fallen "out of status" and is deportable.

https://www.irs.gov/individuals/international-taxpayers/immigration-terms-and-definitions-involving-aliens

Comment: If the FBI or NSA believed that members of Trump's inner circle were negotiating foreign policy with Russia or any other foreign government prior to his inauguration, then under the Logan Act, they were legally obligated to investigate what would be a criminal matter.  While a congratulatory call from President Putin to President-elect Trump may have been understandable after the election, the volume of apparent communications between Trump insiders and Russian government officials would appear to give rise to concerns as to what was being discussed.  This could have warranted a wire tap if there was probable cause that a violation of the Logan Act was being committed.

However, it is highly improbable that President Obama would have authorized or been aware of this unless there was evidence that Trump insiders were negotiating foreign policy.  In particular, Trump's NSA nominee Michael Flynn's communications with Russian officials are already being examined in this regard.
